thread.title: Why Alphabet isn’t Google’s exclusive domain
thread.title_full: Why Alphabet isn’t Google’s exclusive domain - The Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: Why Alphabet isn’t Google’s exclusive domain
text:
NEW DELHI: Google announced the creation of its parent company under the name Alphabet on Monday but clarified that it did not intend to build products and brands under the name.
While making the announcement, Larry Page, a Google co-founder and CEO of the new Alphabet, said: "(W)e are not intending for this to be a big consumer brand with related products — the whole point is that Alphabet companies should have independence and develop their own brands."
The name was chosen, Page said, because the alphabet represents language, one of humanity's most important innovations, and is the "core of how we index" in a Google Internet search.
The name 'Alphabet' is commonly used among businesses and would lead Google into a number of legal disputes for potentially trampling on the trademark rights of others.
In addition to the hundreds of small businesses with Alphabet in their names, there are currently 103 trademark registrations in the United States that include the word "alphabet" or some close variation, according to a database search of the US Patent and Trademark Office.
The registrations include computer games, clothing labels, furniture, toys, all manner of children's books, as well as Alphabet Vodka and the Alphabet City Brewing Co in New York City. There is also the ever-familiar Alpha-Bits breakfast cereal.
READ ALSO:
Google to become Alphabet Inc in shakeup
In fact, even the domain name alphabet.com will not be easily available to the company. A who.is search reveals that it is owned by auto-company BMW and is the name of the fleet management division of the group. Google will have to steer clear of the 'alphabet' name when it christens its self-driving cars division.
The Twitter handle @alphabet is also controlled by Chris Andrikanich. One can read between the lines of his last tweet:
Well, that was an interesting way to end a Monday...
— Chris Andrikanich (@alphabet) August 10, 2015 Interestingly, Alphabet's homepage is located at a rather unconventional URL - abc.xyz. The page features Larry Page's announcement letter, at the moment. The creation of the page has brought some good news to Daniel Negari who is the founder and CEO of XYZ.com, an internet domain registry that owns the suffix .xyz.
Speaking with CNBC, Negari reported that following Google's announcement he was witnessing all kinds of names being registered and got 250 registrations in just 60 seconds. Typically, about 3,000 .xyz domain names are registered in one day. He did not reveal how much Goggle spent on the domain citing a confidentiality agreement.
It appears that Microsoft has already started trolling Google/Alphabet as the domain name xyz.wtf redirects to the Redmond giant's search engine Bing. While the domain listing is private the IP address of the registrant points to the Microsoft headquarters as per Search Engine Land.
With inputs from Reuters http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/followceleb.cms?alias=Google Alphabet,abc.xyz,abc.wtf
